_source.abstract: He’s a bad show, but it’s not low-flow.
_source.lead_paragraph: We’re now officially trudging through the new year. (And good luck on that healthier-living resolution.) This is when we adjust to the fact that nothing has changed. You weren’t allowed to toss Donald Trump out with the old. Although it would have been nice if he’d at least have stayed quiet until all of the Christmas trees were down.
_source.keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']

_source.Titres: Why Did One-Quarter of the World’s Pigs Die in a Year?
_source.abstract: Swine fever devastated China’s stock because with unsound governance, even sound regulations have perverse effects.
_source.lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to my hometown by the Yangtze River in eastern China, relatives welcomed me, as ever, with a feast: steamed perch and hairy crab, deep-fried river shrimp — and braised pork. My 84-year-old father made sure to serve pork, even though it was now twice as expensive as the year before. This time, he didn’t get the meat from my brother, who until this fall had been the village’s largest pork producer: All 150 pigs on my brother’s farm had either died or been culled because of African swine fever.
_source.keywords: ['Pigs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Pork', 'Livestock Diseases', 'Slaughterhouses', 'Politics and Government', 'AFRICAN SWINE FEVER', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Epidemics']

_source.Titres: N.B.A. Superstars, Growth and Lockouts: The David Stern Years
_source.abstract: The longtime commissioner received acclaim for building the league into a vital global business, but he also was at the center of contentious disputes.
_source.lead_paragraph: David Joel Stern was born in Manhattan on Sept. 22, 1942. It was the day after Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, and the Nazi march east through Europe was grinding to a halt outside Stalingrad. Closer to home, the Dodgers topped the Giants, 9-8, in extra innings at Brooklyn’s Ebbets Field.

_source.Titres: In Rose Bowl Victory Over Wisconsin, Oregon Shows Rebuild Needs Work
_source.abstract: The Ducks managed to win with only 204 yards in total offense — the fewest by a team in the Rose Bowl since 1979.
_source.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — If it was not exactly a decisive moment in the 106th Rose Bowl game, it was nevertheless a moment for which these Oregon Ducks had been built.

_source.Titres: Where Darth Vader Gets His Strength
_source.abstract: Ed Sessa turns the lights out on us.
_source.lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When anyone begins a new endeavor — let’s say they start solving crossword puzzles — it is easiest to learn when the overall format is at least somewhat predictable. This is why we encourage new solvers to start with Monday puzzles, where the theme entries are often positioned in roughly the same places and are highly visible. Or at least recognizable.

_source.Titres: Don Larsen, Yankee Who Pitched Only Perfect Game in World Series History, Dies at 90
_source.abstract: He retired after 14 seasons with a losing record for his career, but for one day in 1956 he was the picture of perfection.
_source.lead_paragraph: Don Larsen, an otherwise ordinary pitcher who achieved the extraordinary when he threw the only perfect game in World Series history, died on Wednesday in Hayden Lake, Idaho. He was 90.

_source.Titres: India Cold Wave Breaks Records, Shuts Schools and Makes Bad Air Worse
_source.abstract: Across the north, including New Delhi, plunging temperatures have caused a run on shelters in a region more used to extreme heat.
_source.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A brutal cold wave has swept northern India, blanketing streets in freezing fog, intensifying pollution, disrupting hundreds of flights and prompting school closures.

_source.Titres: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Breakthrough’ and ‘Surviving R. Kelly Part II’
_source.abstract: A drama based on a miraculous Missouri incident airs on HBO. And Lifetime airs a follow-up to its much-viewed R. Kelly documentary series.
_source.lead_paragraph: BREAKTHROUGH (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO. A tragedy happens on ice — and an apparent miracle happens off it — in this faith-based drama from the TV veteran Roxann Dawson. The screenplay is based on an actual 2015 incident in which John Smith, a Missouri teenager, fell through the frozen surface of a lake and remained submerged long enough for his heart to stop. It started pumping blood again after he was brought to a hospital — but reportedly only when his mother audibly prayed for him. That event and the community’s subsequent push to aid in John’s recovery are at the center of this movie, which follows John (Marcel Ruiz), his mother (Chrissy Metz) and father (Josh Lucas) and a young pastor (Topher Grace). The film “tells the story of John’s miraculous ordeal with an unassuming simplicity, focusing on the harrowing details of the case without an overreliance on proselytization,” Bilge Ebiri wrote in his review for The New York Times. Though faith is ever-present, he added, “the film also wisely dedicates plenty of screen time to the emergency workers and doctors struggling to bring the boy back to life. Here, religion is not in contention with medicine, but seems to work in tandem with it.”

_source.Titres: Taiwan’s Top Military Official and 7 Others Die in Helicopter Crash
_source.abstract: The helicopter was carrying military personnel to an event in northeastern Taiwan when it went down on a wooded mountainside.
_source.lead_paragraph: Eight people including the chief of Taiwan’s armed forces were killed Thursday after the military helicopter carrying them crashed on a mountainside during a routine trip, Taiwan’s military said.
_source.keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Helicopters', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
